channel.title: Drive Tesla
channel.description: Your source for everything Tesla & EV

item.title: Tesla brings back free lifetime Supercharging on Model S in the US
item.dc:creator: Darryn John
item.description:
Tesla has added a new incentive on the Model S, something that it has not offered for a long time. According to a new message on the Design Studio in the United States, customers who […]

The post Tesla brings back free lifetime Supercharging on Model S in the US appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
Tesla has added a new incentive on the Model S, something that it has not offered for a long time. According to a new message on the Design Studio in the United States, customers who purchase or lease a new Model S will enjoy free Supercharging for the duration of their ownership.

The new free Supercharging offer applies only to new Model S vehicles purchased or leased on or after December 13, 2024. The benefit is tied to the owner’s Tesla account, meaning it cannot be transferred to another vehicle, person, or order, even if the vehicle is sold.

Tesla does say however that they can removed your lifetime free Supercharging if “in the event of excessive charging or unpaid fees related to Supercharging.” Tesla did not elaborate on what the threshold for “excessive charging” is.

This incentive can be staked with other current promotions. The same incentive is not available on the Model X, it has 3 months of free Supercharging on new orders.

Tesla’s free lifetime Supercharging dates back to the early days of the Model S. When the company launched the Model S in 2012, free unlimited Supercharging was included as a standard feature, a move that helped establish Tesla in the automotive industry.

The offer was phased out in early 2017 as Tesla sought to improve the financial sustainability of its rapidly expanding Supercharger network.

Since then, Tesla has occasionally revived free Supercharging as a limited-time incentive to drive sales during key periods. The company has also sometimes allowed owners with lifetime free Supercharging to transfer it to a new vehicle.

While the return of free lifetime Supercharging is a nice perk, it has come with a cost. Also on Friday Tesla increased prices on both the Model S All-Wheel Drive (AWD) and Plaid by $5,000 in the US.

The post Tesla brings back free lifetime Supercharging on Model S in the US appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Tesla increases Model S prices by $5,000 in the US
item.dc:creator: Darryn John
item.description:
For the first time in a while, Tesla has adjusted its vehicle prices, this time targeting the Model S. According to an update to the Design Studio on Friday, the price of both trims of […]

The post Tesla increases Model S prices by $5,000 in the US appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
For the first time in a while, Tesla has adjusted its vehicle prices, this time targeting the Model S. According to an update to the Design Studio on Friday, the price of both trims of the Model S has increased by $5,000 in the United States. The base Model S All-Wheel Drive (AWD) now starts at $79,990, up from $74,990, while the Model S Plaid carries a new price tag of $94,990, up from $89,990.

There have been no changes to pricing for any of the other models, and there have been no similar price changes in Canada.

This price adjustment is Tesla’s first major change to the Model S lineup in several months. The last time Tesla adjusted prices on its flagship sedan was back in July, when the company raised prices on both the Model S and Model X in Canada by as much as $6,000, and in the United States by $2,000.

Tesla’s decision to raise prices comes at an interesting time, and while Tesla has been known to adjust pricing frequently, the $5,000 increase stands out for two reasons. The first is that it is a significant jump, especially when combined with the earlier price increase in July, making the Model S $7,000 more expensive than it was five months ago.

ALSO READ: Tesla brings back free lifetime Supercharging on Model S in the US

The second is the lackluster sales seen by the Model S recently. The company now lumps together sales of the Model S, Model X, and Cybertruck into the “other” category. Based on sales of the Cybertruck, which we’ve been able to get a pretty accurate figure of from recalls, indicate Model S/X sales were as low as 10,000-12,000 in the third quarter, compared to nearly 20,000 reported in the same quarter in 2023.

Add in the fact that Tesla is aiming for a record quarter of deliveries, pushing for more than 515,000 units in the final three months of the year, and the timing of a $5,000 price increase is a little surprising.

Why do you think Tesla raised the price of the Model S in the US? Let us know in the comments below.

The post Tesla increases Model S prices by $5,000 in the US appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Drive Into the Holidays: The Ultimate Jowua Tesla Accessories Gift Guide for 2024
item.dc:creator: Deals
item.description:
The holiday season is upon us, and if you have a Tesla enthusiast on your list, look no further—this list of top accessories from Jowua is sure to bring joy and practicality to their holiday […]

The post Drive Into the Holidays: The Ultimate Jowua Tesla Accessories Gift Guide for 2024 appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
The holiday season is upon us, and if you have a Tesla enthusiast on your list, look no further—this list of top accessories from Jowua is sure to bring joy and practicality to their holiday season. Remember to use the coupon code DRIVETESLA at checkout for more savings per product.

Tesla Gaming Controller (Wireless Charging)

Price: $75.00

Take your Tesla gaming experience to the next level. Available in three different colours, these controllers connect via Bluetooth and work seamlessly with Tesla’s built-in games. You can pair and connect up to four controllers with the available USB dongle and hub to play the new Boomerang Fu game with your friends! They even charge wirelessly on the charging pad in your Tesla.

6D Tesla Compatible Invisible Foldaway Car Mount Qi2 Wireless Charger (MagSafe)

Price: $118.00

For hands-free convenience, this MagSafe-compatible car mount offers seamless Qi2 wireless charging while blending perfectly with the Tesla’s sleek interior. Perfect for navigation, calls, or entertainment, it’s a gift that’s equal parts style and function.

Car Neck Pillow

Price: $75.00

Long drives just got cozier! This neck pillow is perfect for road trips or daily commutes, ensuring ultimate comfort and support. A must-have for anyone who spends hours behind the wheel.

30L Stackable Storage Box and Trunk Organizer

Price: $154.00

Help your loved one maximize their Tesla’s trunk space with this durable, stackable storage box. Designed to also fit between the rear seats of your Model X for extra storage and an armrest. Ideal for groceries, road trips, and more.

Foldable Car Tray for Tesla

Price: $124.00

This compact, foldable car tray is perfect for meals, work, or hobbies on the go. Whether for road trips or busy commutes, this versatile accessory is a must-have. Families can opt for the bundle version, which includes a backseat accessory kit!

Portable Air Compressor + Charging Solution Kit

Price: $155.00

Winter roads demand extra care. This portable air compressor kit ensures tires are properly inflated, even in the coldest weather. A practical and thoughtful gift for safety-conscious Tesla owners.

Wrap Up the Season with Thoughtful Tesla Gifts 

With this carefully curated Tesla accessories wish list, finding the perfect gift has never been easier. Each item is designed to enhance comfort, convenience, and style, making it the ultimate gift for the Tesla enthusiast in your life. Be sure to check out the entire Jowua store for other great Tesla gift ideas.

Make this holiday season unforgettable—one Tesla accessory at a time! 

Affiliate Disclosure: This post contains income-earning affiliate links, which allows us to continue to deliver the latest Tesla and electric vehicle news. Thank you for your support.

The post Drive Into the Holidays: The Ultimate Jowua Tesla Accessories Gift Guide for 2024 appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Tesla lowers price of in-house wraps, brings back Cybertruck wraps, and expands availability to Washington State
item.dc:creator: Darryn John
item.description:
Tesla has brought back its in-house Cybertruck wrap service. Not only has it returned one month after it disappeared, the wraps are now significantly cheaper, including for the Model 3 and Model Y, and the […]

The post Tesla lowers price of in-house wraps, brings back Cybertruck wraps, and expands availability to Washington State appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
Tesla has brought back its in-house Cybertruck wrap service. Not only has it returned one month after it disappeared, the wraps are now significantly cheaper, including for the Model 3 and Model Y, and the service is now available in Washington State.

Tesla introduced its wrap service in October 2023, initially available exclusively for the Model 3 and Model Y. The service was expanded to include the Cybertruck following its launch a few months later, offering customers a choice between two colours – Matte Black and Satin White.

The colour choices expanded to as many as 11, but they were pricey – as much as US$8,000 for the Cybertruck and US$6,500 for the Model 3/Y. The service was also only available at three Service Centers in California, and briefly available at one location in Texas.

Last month Tesla removed the Cybertruck wrap option from its online shop, but kept the service for the Model 3 and Model Y. Now the service has returned for the Cybertruck, at a lower price, with the discounts extending to the Model 3 and Model Y.

According to the updated Tesla Shop listing, Cybertruck wraps now cost US$4,500, and Model 3/Y wraps cost US$4,000. The listing no longer shows what colours are available, but based on the images, it looks like some new colours have been introduced, with up to 8 colours available for each vehicle.

Along with the lower prices, Tesla is now also offering their wraps out of their Service Center in Seattle, Washington. The original locations in West Covina, Oceanside, Costa Mesa and Santa Clara remain.

The post Tesla lowers price of in-house wraps, brings back Cybertruck wraps, and expands availability to Washington State appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Qatar Airways Launches Toronto Route with Starlink-Equipped Boeing 777s
item.dc:creator: Matt Wilson
item.description:
Qatar Airways has celebrated a significant dual milestone this week, marking the launch of its second Canadian destination, Toronto, alongside the successful installation of Starlink high-speed internet on 15 of its Boeing 777 aircraft. Toronto […]

The post Qatar Airways Launches Toronto Route with Starlink-Equipped Boeing 777s appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
Qatar Airways has celebrated a significant dual milestone this week, marking the launch of its second Canadian destination, Toronto, alongside the successful installation of Starlink high-speed internet on 15 of its Boeing 777 aircraft.

Toronto now joins Montreal as Qatar Airways’ second Canadian destination, with the inaugural non-stop flight between Hamad International Airport in Doha and Toronto Pearson International Airport touching down at YYZ on December 12.

Qatar Airways continues to improve the in-flight experience with its adoption of Starlink internet. As the first airline to equip Boeing 777s with this technology, Qatar Airways provided Toronto-bound passengers with seamless connectivity, allowing for activities such as streaming, gaming, and working during their entire flight, from the moment they board until the plane arrives at the gate at its destination.

Qatar Airways has exceeded its own expectations. Initially targeting 12 aircraft for this upgrade by the end of 2024, the airline is ahead of schedule, fitting 15 777s with Starlink in just 55 days.

The Toronto-Doha route operates three times weekly, every Wednesday, Friday, and Sunday. Each flight departs Doha at 8:10 a.m. and arriving in Toronto at 2:15 p.m. The return journey departs Toronto at 8:00 p.m., arriving in Doha the following afternoon.

We are pleased to announce our first flight to Toronto!

Now flying three times weekly #QatarAirways #GoingPlacesTogether pic.twitter.com/FWp4qcvynG

— Qatar Airways (@qatarairways) December 12, 2024

The post Qatar Airways Launches Toronto Route with Starlink-Equipped Boeing 777s appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: SpaceX Proposes Turning Starbase Into an Official Texas City
item.dc:creator: Matt Wilson
item.description:
SpaceX is petitioning to turn its Starbase facility in South Texas into an officially incorporated city. Located near Boca Chica Beach on the southern tip of Texas near the US/Mexico border, the Starbase site has […]

The post SpaceX Proposes Turning Starbase Into an Official Texas City appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
SpaceX is petitioning to turn its Starbase facility in South Texas into an officially incorporated city. Located near Boca Chica Beach on the southern tip of Texas near the US/Mexico border, the Starbase site has already hosts the production and testing of SpaceX’s massive Starship rockets.

Now, CEO Elon Musk wants to transform the area into a community that supports their mission to make humanity a multiplanetary species.

On December 12, SpaceX submitted a formal request to Cameron County Judge Eddie Treviño Jr., asking for a local election to decide whether the site should be incorporated. Kathryn Lueders, the general manager of Starbase, detailed the rationale in the letter, emphasizing the need for infrastructure and amenities to attract and retain top talent.

“To continue growing the workforce necessary to rapidly develop and manufacture Starship, we need the ability to grow Starbase as a community,” the letter stated.

The proposed incorporation would streamline the development of housing, schools, medical facilities, and other essential services for the 3,400 full-time employees and contractors currently working at Starbase. Lueders also noted that SpaceX already manages several public functions in the area, such as utilities, roads, and even education.

By establishing Starbase as an official city, these responsibilities could transition to public governance.

Musk has been vocal about his vision for Starbase for years, first hinting at the idea in a 2021 social media post. While discussions about incorporation have been ongoing, this marks the first time SpaceX has officially filed a petition.

Musk commented on the petition on X, saying, “SpaceX HQ will now officially be in the city of Starbase, Texas!” However, Musk was getting a little ahead of himself, as the county’s legal and election teams will review the request to ensure compliance with statutory requirements before proceeding and approving the petition.

The move to turn Starbase into its own city comes amid Musk’s broader shift of operations to Texas, a state he has praised for its business-friendly environment. Earlier this year, SpaceX headquarters moved from Hawthorne, California, to Starbase, and Musk announced plans to relocate the headquarters of his social media platform X to Austin. These decisions followed Musk’s dissatisfaction with California’s regulatory landscape, which he criticized as stifling innovation.

SpaceX HQ will now officially be in the city of Starbase, Texas! https://t.co/zpN4t3mJQT

— Elon Musk (@elonmusk) December 13, 2024

The post SpaceX Proposes Turning Starbase Into an Official Texas City appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Tesla announces Actually Smart Summon for China
item.dc:creator: Darryn John
item.description:
Tesla has officially announced the availability of Actually Smart Summon (ASS) in China. Announced via Tesla’s official Weibo account, the feature enables Tesla vehicles equipped with Full Self-Driving (FSD) or Enhanced Autopilot (EAP) software to […]

The post Tesla announces Actually Smart Summon for China appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
Tesla has officially announced the availability of Actually Smart Summon (ASS) in China. Announced via Tesla’s official Weibo account, the feature enables Tesla vehicles equipped with Full Self-Driving (FSD) or Enhanced Autopilot (EAP) software to autonomously navigate from parking spaces to a designated location near the driver.

In China, one of the world’s most competitive electric vehicle (EV) markets, the Actually Smart Summon feature will be delivered through over-the-air (OTA) software update. However, just like in North America, the feature is limited to owners with EAP or FSD, which cost ¥32,000 (C$6,250/US$4,390) and ¥64,000 (C$12,500/US$8,780) respectively.

To further entice buyers, Tesla has introduced a promotion offering 90 days of free Enhanced Autopilot access for customers who purchase a Tesla vehicle through a trade-in. This follows an earlier incentive program in which trade-in customers were entered into a lottery for a chance to tour Giga Shanghai.

While Tesla has announced the availability of ASS in China, it actually hasn’t arrived on any vehicles yet, as the software update that enables the feature will likely be released around the Spring Festival in late January. As a result, it remains to be seen if ASS will have the same functionality as it does in North America in regards to the distance the vehicle can travel autonomously, and how close the driver has to be to the vehicle.

Last month Tesla released a severely limited version of ASS in Europe and the Middle East, in which the feature only operates when the driver is within 6 meters (19.5 feet) of the car, and the car can only travel about 15 meters (50 feet) in total.

Actually Smart Summon (ASS) has launched in China pic.twitter.com/4PT5RJEqci

— Drive Tesla (@DriveTeslaca) December 13, 2024

The post Tesla announces Actually Smart Summon for China appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Green NCAP Awards Tesla Model 3 Top Efficiency Rating
item.dc:creator: David Odejide
item.description:
The Tesla Model 3 continues to gather global accolades as it clears top rating and scores for electric vehicle (EV) efficiency from Green NCAP. Green NCAP, a Europe-based independent initiative that promotes clean and efficient […]

The post Green NCAP Awards Tesla Model 3 Top Efficiency Rating appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
The Tesla Model 3 continues to gather global accolades as it clears top rating and scores for electric vehicle (EV) efficiency from Green NCAP.

Green NCAP, a Europe-based independent initiative that promotes clean and efficient mobility, has awarded the 2024 Tesla Model 3 RWD the highest rating. The sedan received 5 stars and a 98% total score for achieving high efficiency. The organization cites the EV’s aerodynamics, lighter weight, and powertrain as contributing factors.

Tesla Europe & Middle East shared the news on its X account.

New Model 3 achieves record-low energy consumption figures in Green NCAP test, earning it a 5-star rating with an avg score of 98%https://t.co/6TTf0jRJMg

— Tesla Europe & Middle East (@teslaeurope) December 12, 2024

According to figures published by Green NCAP, the Tesla Model Y consumed only 14.2 kWh/100 km during testing on the road in dry and sunny weather with temperatures around 20 degrees Celsius. This would have netted 475 km of driving range, a spectacular achievement with the Model Y’s 60 kWh battery pack. It performed even better on inner-city roads, posting 12.4 kWh/100 km and 547 km between charges.

Green NCAP acknowledged the improvements Tesla has made to the Model Y in just two years, “In 2022 Green NCAP tested a Tesla Model 3 for the first time and the vehicle set new standards for energy efficiency. Today, the result of the new Model 3 are even more impressive.”

The Model 3 remains a popular car in Europe, with the Mandelieu-La Napoule police force hoping to cut operating expenses by 85 percent by incorporating it into its patrol fleet.

The post Green NCAP Awards Tesla Model 3 Top Efficiency Rating appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Tesla Cybertruck gets a step closer to launch in China
item.dc:creator: Darryn John
item.description:
The Tesla Cybertruck may soon make its way to the Chinese market despite recent denials from Tesla China. The company has completed a significant regulatory filing, receiving an Automobile Energy Consumption Label from China’s Ministry […]

The post Tesla Cybertruck gets a step closer to launch in China appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
The Tesla Cybertruck may soon make its way to the Chinese market despite recent denials from Tesla China. The company has completed a significant regulatory filing, receiving an Automobile Energy Consumption Label from China’s Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT).

While this does not confirm an imminent launch, the approval has reignited speculation about Tesla’s plans for the electric pickup in one of the world’s largest electric vehicle (EV) markets.

As we reported earlier this week, Tesla China denied any immediate plans to introduce the Cybertruck to the region. Furthermore, Tesla CEO Elon Musk has previously expressed skepticism about the feasibility of making the Cybertruck road-legal in China, citing the challenges of compliance with local regulations.

Despite these statements, the approval suggests that Tesla is at least exploring the possibility.

The energy consumption label posted the MIIT website provides some interesting details about the Cybertruck’s specifications in China. The vehicle boasts a range of 618km (384 miles). Perhaps most importantly, the Cybertruck is classified as an M1 passenger vehicle rather than a traditional truck.

This classification could get Tesla around restrictive regulations that typically apply to light trucks in China, such as being subject to annual inspections, mandatory scrapping after 15 years, and having restricted access to many urban areas, all of which limit their broader appeal.

Despite the approval, launching the Cybertruck in China is far from straightforward. The vehicle must still meet stringent requirements for pedestrian safety and other local standards. Furthermore, Tesla might consider developing a modified version of the Cybertruck tailored to international markets, though there has obviously been no official confirmation on that front.

The post Tesla Cybertruck gets a step closer to launch in China appeared first on Drive Tesla.

item.title: Tesla Supercharger in Brockville opens after 7-year wait [Ontario]
item.dc:creator: Darryn John
item.description:
Tesla owners in Ontario can finally celebrate as the long-awaited Supercharger in Brockville, Ontario, is officially open. The journey to this opening has been unusually long, even by Tesla standards. Originally announced in 2018 with […]

The post Tesla Supercharger in Brockville opens after 7-year wait [Ontario] appeared first on Drive Tesla.
item.content:encoded:
Tesla owners in Ontario can finally celebrate as the long-awaited Supercharger in Brockville, Ontario, is officially open.

The journey to this opening has been unusually long, even by Tesla standards. Originally announced in 2018 with an expected location at SmartCentres Brockville on Parkedale Avenue, the project saw multiple delays, shifting timelines, and even locations.

It quickly became a running joke among Ontario Tesla owners, with many doubting it would ever materialize. It took a while, but construction finally began in early 2023 at 125 Stewart Blvd, leading many to believe it would open soon. However, even after the start on construction, the delays continued as the site was completed but sat idle and covered up for nearly a year.

On the same day the Tesla share prices reached a new record high, the curse was finally lifted and the 8-stall V3 Brockville Supercharger is now open. According to the mobile app, it costs $0.67/kWh to plug in and charge.

Brockville’s new Supercharger will play a key role in bridging gaps in the Tesla charging network in this part of Ontario, particularly along the Highway 401 corridor between Kingston and Cornwall.

In other Ontario Supercharger news, construction has just started on a new station in Oakville. Tesla is also currently building Superchargers in Ingersoll and Severn, with another in Severn expected to follow soon.

The post Tesla Supercharger in Brockville opens after 7-year wait [Ontario] appeared first on Drive Tesla.
